job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Great location, attached to NSLS-II, close-ish to NYC, and overall great work culture as the premier research university on Long Island. Opportunities are abundant, for both career advancement and research. Usually you would have a little bit of flexibility in work hours rather than stick to 9 to 5, depending on the group you join. Good schools for your children. Unions are strong, at least for now. Sunrise at Montauk lighthouse is a life changing experience and is only one and a half hour away.
cons: Rent is expensive (anything close to NYC is). Administration could be sluggish depending on the department. Some groups are notorious for pushing people hard, unnecessarily so. Be wary.

review_title: Stony Brook does not care about researchers
job_title: Research Scientist in Stony Brook, NY
pros: If your passion is doing significant research with some of the brightest people dedicated to developing therapies to treat devastating diseases, and you don't mind obstacles, then Stony Brook is a place you can do that.
cons: Stony Brook does not care about basic research or the research support staff that are critical for the success of academic science. Bright fancy buildings and embarrassingly obsolete core facilities to support research are what to expect here. Stony Brook administrators will cry poverty every chance they get. Of course, their salaries are quite healthy. Do not dismiss this as a rant, it's a fact that many administrative assistants with NO degrees make more money than scientists and postdocs. They can afford to live on Long Island. Make no mistake, this place is expensive and scientist salaries do not cut it here. What are the priorities at Stony Brook when administrators, tasked with supporting the research mission of the university, feel as if researchers and their staff are a burden? I really don't know. Stay away from here if you can.

review_title: Good support from University, but research experience depends on group/department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros:
1. In small groups, research freedom and breadth of experience gained
2. In large groups, name recognition in academic community and access to research tools
3. University has recently started openly supporting graduate researchers and TAs by increasing base salary to keep up with Long Island housing market, keeping benefits at low cost, and emphasizing work-life balance to ensure prosperity
cons:
1. In small groups, limited name recognition and lack of access to tools or collaborations; also, success of entire project falls on one/two graduate researchers, and limited guidance by lead group PI (actual guidance comes from senior graduate students or post-docs)
2. In large groups, can feel like just a "cog in the wheel" with limited breadth of research tasks, and limited research freedom or control as projects are decided by PI / post-docs who will promise theory-based results always better than realistic experimental-based possible outcomes
3. Stony Brook is a large public/state research university, so it relies on graduate students to do most of the teaching responsibilities of the Professors so they can be full-time PIs on research projects; expect to work hard at teaching to keep undergrad students up to speed with professors' expectations

review_title: Doing PhD here (or anywhere, but especially here) is hard
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros:
- Great health insurance
- Being able to park in Faculty/Staff lots for free on campus (provided that you live off-campus)
- Suffolk county is pretty safe
cons:
- Low pay vs. the extremely high cost of living in this area - $30k/yr is only 30% of Suffolk County’s median income and less than half of the NYS median income. You’ll have to live with many roommates in a house of the subpar condition and deal with private landowners —serviced apartments are few and hardly affordable unless your parents are willing to support you with extra money. Worse still, the university did not waive student fees for PhDs until Spring 2021. If you can’t do internships in the industry during summers for extra income, you will live a miserable life.
- No work-life balance because you are expected to devote yourself to research all the time. There is no such thing as PTO. Meetings go as usual even if it’s Thanksgiving or Christmas week and you are expected to make progress even in holiday weeks.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Stony Brook, NY
pros: I've had an amazing PI because of his support and connections.  My project is a collaboration between government, academia, and industry, so I'm not stuck in a bubble. The project is both fundamental and applied, which makes it a surprisingly fun project (not a common theme in grad school).  I'm grateful for the support, and the proximity to Brookhaven National Lab is large bonus in terms of access. People in the I like that it has a train station for the Long Island Railroad, which makes getting to New York City endurable.
cons: Small pay, although I am paid more than most graduate students.  Perhaps the worst part is the terrible administration of the university.  Excessive paperwork, one hand not aware of the other, and the general lack of resources.  My department is hampered by the usual political agendas of its faculty, and grant money is a continuing problem, but that problem is common to nearly all science departments these days.  My lab is utterly dependent on aging equipment that get by on cannibalized components. The user interface for purchasing materials and equipment is horrid due to the intentional complexity; more hoops to jump through than necessary.  People who have been with this institution longer than me have noted of the incremental decline in the overall management.  Something has go to give, and I'm glad to be out of there before it really hits the fan.

job_title: Student Caller in Stony Brook, NY
pros: The management you deal with on a regular basis are looking out for your best interest, both professionally and personally. Any problems can be discussed in person or private during or after a work shift. The enthusiasm of the work place drives people to do a good job, which is to say nothing of the free food and bonuses awarded to top callers. Additionally, even though you're on the phone for the entire shift, 15 minute breaks and a light hearted atmosphere motivate staff to work harder. That positive energy helps push shifts along faster than anywhere I've ever worked before.
cons: You're on the phone for hours on end and the number of refusals you get can really be mentally defeating. Because management is constantly offering incentives for top caller or top credit card pledge, not getting these bonuses on a regular basis could probably get depressing. Also, if you don't make the cut or if you have a bad night, you won't get fired; however, management has not problem whatsoever discussing your "approach" to calling alumni and will most assuredly ask you to improve specific aspects of your calling. If you improve you're congratulated. If you don't, expect to get canned.

review_title: I have had an amazing time working in an environment that is constantly changing.
job_title: Student Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Great working environment, the type of work varies from client to client encouraging you to think outside the box to solve their problems. As a student employee, I was given a lot of flexibility in my schedule so that I could schedule around classes while working 40 hours a week. Assisting with education, its rewarding knowing you're making an impact.
cons: Sometimes, faculty expect a bit too much not knowing the cost of what they are requesting. But as far as management is concerned, the only thing I've ever seen an issue with is that the different departments tend not to work cohesively together. There are many idiosyncrasies that make the school look a bit unorganized.

review_title: If you are lucky to find the good people, you will excel.
job_title: Senior Staff Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Large organization, good benefits, some good people to offset the lazy ones.
cons: Large organization--lots of favoritism, lots of ignoring state policies and regulations to satisfy personal needs, many are grossly overpaid and others grossly underpaid.  Don't get me wrong-there are some outstanding people working here, but they are outnumbered by the cliche state workers, who have that "it's not in my job description" attitude.  If you're lucky to fall into a position working for one of the good people, you will love it.  Otherwise, don't bother trying to do your best because it won't matter one bit.  Don't bother reporting anyone either, or you'll make a heck of a lot of trouble for yourself.  Unions-useless.  Labor Relations-useless.  A lot of topheavy depts. with really bad management.

job_title: Senior Staff Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: The benefits and location are good.
cons:
There is no room for growth. Unless your own department has higher positions available and is interested in promoting you, or you have someone at the top pulling strings for you, it is impossible to move up. All jobs higher than staff assistant are routinely given to those already in the department advertising the position. There are too many faux interviews being conducted which wastes everyone's time. It doesn't matter if one fits a position. Departments know how to word things on the hiring paperwork to be able to hire the internal person it wants in the position. 

Even the executive "leadership" doesn't follow proper hiring process and appoints whomever they want in a specific position.

The current president is such a poor leader that his entire leadership team has left, only to be replaced with others who leave six months later.

The university survives despite the current poor leadership due to the dedication of the faculty and staff to the students.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Stony Brook, NY
pros: public sea-grant and space-grant research university located in Stony Brook, New York in the United States. It is part of the State University of New York system
cons: if u want to a nap between classes, u can't go anywhere that is halfway quiet, and once i even got told by a police officer that i couldnt sleep in my car, although i was in the south p, and in my own car. what's unusual about stony brook is the huge campus, with classes in the most desolate, creepy areas, and only 10 minutes inbetween, so if your two classes are on opposite sides of the campus, be prepared to run.

review_title: If you are a female please find another place of employment
job_title: Management in New York, NY
pros: There are no pro's to working in this enviroment, unless you are a 40+ year old man who enjoys belittling, hitting, and stalking your coworkers. The SBU police department isn't going to help. Try having to go all the way to federal court to get someone to listen about the horrors of Stony Brook University! Not safe for women!
cons: Masoginistic men, outdated ideas, tee-party management, corrupt contractors, corrupt administrators, horrendous HR, LR, and ODAA, nepotism, it's all about who you know, not what you know. Worst of all, for having a female VP, this place is atrocious for women, students and staff.

job_title: Residence Hall Director in Stony Brook, NY
pros: This was my first professional job in Student Affairs. I learned how to manage, hire and train staff. I had a lot of resources working in housing, including decent budgets for programming, constant training/professional development and a wealth of colleagues. I had the opportunity to teach an entry-level college course to freshmen, which is one of the most valuable experiences I had. Working 10 months out of the year was a great perk, as well as the free/required on-campus housing provided to staff.
cons: We were expected to work over time on a constant basis without being compensated for our time. The expectations were too high on live-in staff to work and be at so many events and trainings outside of normal hours.

job_title: Associate Prof. in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Great undergraduates; nice location in suburban Long Island; good benefits and freedom to do research.  In terms of benefits, the health insurance and employer 403(b) contributions are particular plusses.  Colleagues are interesting.
cons: Public university = funding and staffing issues; pressure to bring in research money leads to pressure to not focus on education (the goal of a university, surely, is education?).  It is very expensive to live on Long Island and salaries just do not keep up (even to those of peers working in much less expensive locations).  Commonly accepted procedures for faculty review (e.g. mid-tenure-track review) are ignored.

job_title: Graduate Student Teaching Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Unlike most music departments, tasks that are normally reserved for full-time positions are instead distributed in the form of teaching assistant positions. I felt that this was a clear indication that the department is aware of the financial burdens of graduate students and I appreciated their willingness to take an unusual route to fund significant stipends to many students.
cons: Do not expect to have the normal conservatory experience. For example, you might be used to having a stage manager for your recitals. At SB, you are your own stage manager. This is a minor problem, though, in the grand scheme of things, because you and your colleagues are probably getting a scholarship/stipend that would otherwise be unavailable if more regular full time positions were provided at the department.

job_title: Switchboard Operator in Stony Brook, NY
pros: I highly recommend this student job to Stony Brook University students. I started off with $7.25/hour (higher than state minimum wage at the time) then I was earning $9/hour when I graduated. I could do homework while at work, play games, make outside phone calls, it was the perfect work environment. If one needed the day off to study, sleep in or go home early for the weekend you got it. If I was sick, I always could get the day off even though I have gone in to work sick a few times.
cons: Sometimes I wouldn't get the work schedule I wanted. The most I worked in a week (the entire 4 years I worked there) was 14 hours.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: Very good research facility, good research environment. Not to mention it's so close to BNL the national labotory, giving you the luxory of using the state of the art research equipment in the world.
cons: Location of the University is really not the best, as it's inconvenient to travel to New York City where most of the business and resources are. You had to take a train which takes almost 2 hours.  For some majors, the research faculty generally do not have very strong background or enough publishing, making it challenging to get a faculty position after you graduate if you are wishing to get a job in the academia. However, getting a postdoctoral position could be less challenging.

review_title: Terrible place to do Ph.D. research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stony Brook, NY
pros: The biggest pro to Stony Brook is that the faculty are very high quality, especially in the hard sciences and in math. The educational standards are also high, and this seems to be especially so at the graduate level.
cons:
There are many terrible things about Stony Brook. 

-- They can barely afford to maintain the buildings. In my 6 years there, I worked in 4 different offices. 3 of them had no windows, and all of them had temperature control issues - either too hot or too cold. Most of the problems couldn't be fixed when I  or others complained about it - it was just 'how it was'. The Union building had to be shut down because it's in critical condition. They can't afford to clean faculty and grad student offices more than once a year. The desk I had was falling apart. The WifI in the library sucked. There were no outlets to plug my laptop in at the library. The roof used to leak a lot. The stairwells would flood when it rained, and the list goes on.. 

-- The culture [both internal to Stony Brook and endemic to Long Island] is toxic. Very few people are happy there - whether it be undergraduates, graduate students, faculty, or staff. The only people I met who seemed to be happy are administrators (who are paid exorbent salaries to basically pontificate all day about how great and honorable the University is, while doing very little tangible work), and some of the super star faculty, who are given perks and cushy salaries to keep them there. The school was ranked in the top 10 least happy campuses by Princeton Review.

-- Long Island sucks for graduate students any young people (and in general). Long Island is a terrible place to live - extremely high rent, nasty, rude locals, constant and terrible traffic at all times of day, and a lack of sense of community. You are hardpressed to find local culture, it's mostly all mindless dull suburbian sprawl extending in all directions. 

-- Housing situation is terrible for Ph.D. students. Grad students are forced to live in crowded, poorly maintained houses (some with 6-12 people) and pay $700-$1000 a month just for a room. Apartments in the region are only affordable to Ph.D. students with big loans or trust funds. Salary for grad students is just barely enough to live in the area.
